channel.title: Technology : NPR
channel.description: Latest technology news and breakthroughs in technology, science, and industry. Download the NPR Technology podcast and Technology RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: At School And At Home, How Much Does The Internet Know About Kids?
item.description: Look both ways when you cross the street and don't tell toys your name and address — privacy concerns are some of the latest worries for parents in the digital age.
item.content:encoded: Look both ways when you cross the street and don't tell toys your name and address — privacy concerns are some of the latest worries for parents in the digital age.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: You Can Give A Robot A Paintbrush, But Does It Create Art?
item.description: Pindar Van Arman is a painter — and a software designer. His latest project? A portrait-painting robot. Its paintings "dance on the edge" between creations by humans and machines, he says.
item.content:encoded: Pindar Van Arman is a painter — and a software designer. His latest project? A portrait-painting robot. Its paintings "dance on the edge" between creations by humans and machines, he says.
item.dc:creator: Allie Caren

item.title: An App That Helps You Scat Sing A La Ella Fitzgerald
item.description: Wanna be the next Ella Fitzgerald or Cab Calloway? As they say, there's an app for that. NPR's Rachel Martin tries out "ScatAbility" with vocal improv educator Michele Weir.
item.content:encoded: Wanna be the next Ella Fitzgerald or Cab Calloway? As they say, there's an app for that. NPR's Rachel Martin tries out "ScatAbility" with vocal improv educator Michele Weir.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Is Betting Tech Can Address Educational Equity. Is It That Simple?
item.description: The Facebook CEO and his wife will deploy billions to improve schools using technology. Critics warn of the dangers of freestanding solutions.
item.content:encoded: The Facebook CEO and his wife will deploy billions to improve schools using technology. Critics warn of the dangers of freestanding solutions.
item.dc:creator: Anya Kamenetz

item.title: #NPRreads: Jihadist Culture, Turkish Delight And A Christian Abortion Provider
item.description: Also this week: How classic video games are teaching computers to learn.
item.content:encoded: Also this week: How classic video games are teaching computers to learn.
item.dc:creator: Annie Johnson

item.title: 5 Things To Know: Net Neutrality Is Back In Court
item.description: Once again, a federal court will decide whether the FCC can keep its Open Internet rules. This time, the challenge centers on the FCC's overhaul of how it regulates Internet providers.
item.content:encoded: Once again, a federal court will decide whether the FCC can keep its Open Internet rules. This time, the challenge centers on the FCC's overhaul of how it regulates Internet providers.
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Yahoo's Board Debates Selling Company's Core Business
item.description: Yahoo's board is meeting amid reports that the company may sell off its struggling Internet business or a huge stake in the Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba. Yahoo is the No. 3 search engine.
item.content:encoded: Yahoo's board is meeting amid reports that the company may sell off its struggling Internet business or a huge stake in the Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba. Yahoo is the No. 3 search engine.
item.dc:creator: Aarti Shahani

item.title: FCC Attorneys Will Be Back In Court To Defend Net Neutrality
item.description: The Obama administration's plan to regulate Internet access like a public utility faces a big hurdle on Friday. Major phone and cable companies are challenging the FCC's Open Internet rules in court.
item.content:encoded: The Obama administration's plan to regulate Internet access like a public utility faces a big hurdle on Friday. Major phone and cable companies are challenging the FCC's Open Internet rules in court.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: This Peanut Farmer Turns To A Cellphone — And Prayer — For A Top Crop
item.description: Mariama Keita of Senegal farms the old-school way: hoes, pitchforks, no tractor. But lately she's relying on a not-so-traditional tool.
item.content:encoded: Mariama Keita of Senegal farms the old-school way: hoes, pitchforks, no tractor. But lately she's relying on a not-so-traditional tool.
item.dc:creator: Ofeibea Quist-Arcton

item.title: The Daredevils Without Landlines — And Why Health Experts Are Tracking Them
item.description: It's not surprising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sees more and more landlines disappear. But who knew wireless-only households were into risky behavior? A CDC researcher explains.
item.content:encoded: It's not surprising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sees more and more landlines disappear. But who knew wireless-only households were into risky behavior? A CDC researcher explains.
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: As Tech Firms Come To Oakland, So Do Hopes Of Racial Diversity
item.description: Oakland, Calif., is known for being diverse. The tech industry? Not so much. But there's hope the situation will improve as more tech companies move to Oakland.
item.content:encoded: Oakland, Calif., is known for being diverse. The tech industry? Not so much. But there's hope the situation will improve as more tech companies move to Oakland.
item.dc:creator: Pendarvis Harshaw

item.title: An LLC? It Gives Facebook Founder More Freedom To Meet Philanthropic Goals
item.description: Creating a for-profit company to manage his $45 billion pledge means Mark Zuckerberg is giving himself flexibility in deciding the best way of tackling the social issues he cares about.
item.content:encoded: Creating a for-profit company to manage his $45 billion pledge means Mark Zuckerberg is giving himself flexibility in deciding the best way of tackling the social issues he cares about.
item.dc:creator: Chris Arnold

item.title: Facebook Founder's Philanthropic Aspirations Highlighted In Announcement
item.description: NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Dale Russakoff, author of the book, The Prize, about what lessons Zuckerberg learned from his $100 million donation to fix Newark, N.J., schools.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Dale Russakoff, author of the book, The Prize, about what lessons Zuckerberg learned from his $100 million donation to fix Newark, N.J., schools.

item.title: Too Much TV And Chill Could Reduce Brain Power Over Time
item.description: Young adults who watch at least three hours of TV a day might end up with less cognitive function by middle age, a study finds. That's especially true if they're sedentary couch potatoes.
item.content:encoded: Young adults who watch at least three hours of TV a day might end up with less cognitive function by middle age, a study finds. That's especially true if they're sedentary couch potatoes.
item.dc:creator: Angus Chen

item.title: A Click Too Far: Why Using Social Media Isn't That Great For Fundraising
item.description: Empathy campaigns can spread like wildfire on Facebook and other social media. So how come data show that social networking sites direct very few clicks to charity donation pages?
item.content:encoded: Empathy campaigns can spread like wildfire on Facebook and other social media. So how come data show that social networking sites direct very few clicks to charity donation pages?
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh
